awd_titl_txt: Dynamics and signal multiplicity in the G protein network
awd_abstract_narration:
All cells are capable of recognizing and responding to signals from their environment. The molecular machinery that carries out this recognition and response has been well described for many signals, and it is recognized that interacting networks of signaling pathways exist. However, a central problem in cell biology is the manner in which these signaling networks interact and are controlled and integrated to produce an appropriate response to multiple signals. This project will explore the design principles of signaling networks that allow cells to process information that includes both the strength and duration of external signals. Experimental and mathematical modeling approaches will be used to gain a systems-level understanding of multiple signal sensing in a plant (Arabidopsis) well-suited to the study of responses to changes in the environment. A new teaching tool for High School students and the curricular materials for their teachers will be created that make explicit the underlying mathematical principles that will allow students of biology to develop and manipulate models of cell signaling. 

This project will establish systems-level properties of the glucose/pathogen (PAMP) sensing system of Arabidopsis, building on the emergent property of "dose-duration reciprocity" formulated using the glucose response in the heterotrimeric G protein pathway. The specific aims of the project address 1) The emergent properties conferred by network architecture on the glucose response systems, 2) the manner in which multiple signals can operate through a single complex to generate different outcomes, and 3) the manner in which the dynamics of subcellular location of system components regulate the cellular response outcomes.

por.por_cntn:
All cells sense environmental signals and respond to changing conditions. Signals that are sensed such as light or a pathogen are dynamic.  For example, light intensity and duration varies due to clouds and shadows and pathogen levels go up and down due to an arms race between the pathogen and plant. On top of fast dynamics, light also slowly increases and decreases due to earth rotation.  In many cases, these signals are detected by membrane-bound receptors that activate intracellular signaling pathways. These pathways process and propagate information about the environment and initiate appropriate cellular responses. While much is known about the proteins that comprise signaling pathways, much less is known about the molecular control mechanisms used to regulate signal activity. An important problem in systems biology is to understand the design principles of signaling networks that allow eukaryotic cells to process multi-dimensional information, such as the amplitude and duration of external signals, and respond appropriately. In this project, we combined experimental investigation with mathematical modeling to gain a systems-level understanding of multiple signal sensing in Arabidopsis, a paragon for environment-dependent signal transduction in autotrophic plants. We discovered that a single signaling core of 4 identified proteins, a signaling complex, associates with a different sensor that detects a specific signal.  These complexes behave as an on-off switch that has four key states made from two independent cycles: one cycle is D>T>D and the other is a phosphorylation/dephosphorylation cycle that adds or removes a phosphate to both the D and T states. This 4-state switch has the extraordinary property of detecting change in signals when the environment is noisy with a baseline that is also changing such as the daily light cycle: noon>dusk>midnight>dawn>noon. The different cycles are controlled by different signals providing the answer to how multiple signals interact to switch cell behavior. This new understanding has enabled us a means to engineer plants with different signal response properties such as speed and quality control.   For example, compare a switch that elicits a rapid response even if a false positive (e.g. misinterpreting a stick for a poisonous snake) but little cost (e.g. jumping away) vs. a switch that is slow but accurate and intolerant to false positives (e.g. misinterpreting a mild cold snap for the winter).  This new understanding of plant signal switches could be applied to physical switches such in computers.  This NSF-funded project also determined how these switches are created within the cell.
